headline: Ohio Senate candidate Mike Gibbons spent big money to be on your TV. Is it paying off?
author: Haley BeMiller
sentences: In Hilliard, Gibbons also made vague comments about Mandel's "baggage" that could come out during the general election, a reference to his divorce records that the Cincinnati Enquirer has sued to unseal.

Haley BeMiller is a reporter for the USA TODAY Network Ohio Bureau, which serves the Columbus Dispatch, Cincinnati Enquirer, Akron Beacon Journal and 18 other affiliated news organizations across Ohio.

Still, Gibbons appears to have momentum and could scoop up more voters who are undecided, said Kyle Kondik, managing editor of Sabato's Crystal Ball, an online political newsletter.
After months on air, internal and independent surveys show Gibbons gaining in the polls and giving presumptive frontrunner former state Treasurer Josh Mandel a run for his money.
Gibbons hits many of the same issues as his opponents – think border security and inflation – and argued President Joe Biden took too long to confront Russia over Ukraine.

'More twists and turns'
Gibbons, a former Kenyon College football player, launched a $10 million ad blitz last summer to circulate messages laced with football themes.
He said his opponent never worked in the private sector, although Mandel landed well-paid spots on corporate boards and startups between his 2018 and 2022 Senate bids.
The Cleveland investment banker is among five leading GOP candidates hoping to woo voters in the upcoming primary and secure the chance to replace retiring U.S. Sen.
A Fox News poll released this month put Gibbons at 22% over Mandel's 20%, and Gibbons led Mandel by 7 percentage points in a separate survey from Emerson College.

Mandel is now in a relationship with his campaign finance director, who was accused of sowing a toxic work environment that drove out multiple fundraisers.

He ran for the GOP Senate nomination in 2018 against former U.S. Rep. Jim Renacci, who entered the race after Mandel abruptly dropped out.

His campaign is helped by an investment portfolio that's made him among the wealthiest of the wealthy in the GOP primary.
